Signal Flags

This component helps in recognizing text encoded into International maritime signal flags. A complementary reference table also lists the standardized meanings of single-flag messages.

Basic usage

Given a signal flag you want to quickly look up, draw the general features of its shape in the empty rectangle provided. For example, if the flag consists of three horizontal stripes, draw two separating lines dividing the rectangle roughly in thirds. The app will show a selection of flags matching the pattern in decreasing amounts of similarity. If you can see the flag you meant, click it to record the corresponding letter in the Plaintext field.

NB that the app supports multi–line patterns. Please do not attempt to draw disconnected line segments using a single stroke as this drastically reduces the detection success rate. However, make sure the recognition does not commence in the delay between drawing individual parts of the pattern.

Signal Flags will only recognize flags corresponding to letters of the English alphabet. It can not be used to recognize flags signalizing digits, abbreviations or other kinds of signals used in actual maritime communication protocols.

If you are experiencing problems in recognizing certain types of flags, consider drawing their main features more pronounced or even exaggerated. It is not vital for the recognition algorithm to stick exactly to the bounds of the indicated flag shape should this be at the expense of comfort and/or recognition quality.

Preferences

It is possible to fine–tune the delay before the app considers the drawing finished and starts shape recognition. Some delay is necessary for drawing multi–line patterns, however, too long a delay could result in unnecessarily long total input time.

Encryption

Use the Encrypt tab to convert a plaintext into a sequence of signal flags. As opposed to decryption, letters as well as digits are accepted. Digits are mapped to signal flags according to the International Code of Signals (ICS) standard.
